meta.description: Structured decision set for AtlasForge canon lock covering branding, navigation, and public messaging.

blocks.title: Core pillars and how the canon surfaces them
blocks.description: Choose how each AtlasForge pillar is canonized in-world and surfaced on public pages, from hidden lore to hero-level story anchors.

items.label: How prominently should the AtlasForge umbrella be canonized across the site and story?
items.description: Sets whether the AtlasForge banner is treated as a quiet backdrop or a hero identity anchoring every page in the shared universe.

items.label: How visible is the AtlasForge Games pillar in the public canon?
items.description: Controls if Games is a whispered capability or a front-line guild in the narrative, with matching placement on key surfaces.

items.label: How visible is the AtlasForge Media pillar within the canon storyline?
items.description: Determines whether Media is a subtle lore conduit or a featured storytelling wing with clear placement across pages.

items.label: How prominent is the AtlasForge Studio/tools pillar in-world and on the site?
items.description: Sets whether the builder's workshop (AtlasStudio + tools) is a quiet backstage mention or a headlining part of the canon.

items.label: How central should Atlas Engine / Atlas-V be in the public canon narrative?
items.description: Defines how much the creative engine is spotlighted as the mind behind AtlasForge worlds versus kept as internal infrastructure.

items.label: How openly should AtlasForge Merch operate as an in-universe trading post?
items.description: Controls whether merch is a quiet support channel or a visible canon market with its own placement on the site.

items.label: How much do Labs and experimental work appear as canonized pillars?
items.description: Determines if experimental efforts stay in the shadows or receive a named pillar slot in the public-facing story.

items.label: Where should the Contact / Work With Us gateway sit in the canon map?
items.description: Sets whether the doorway for partners and recruits is framed as a subtle link or a major entry point in the storyline and nav.

blocks.title: Brand roles and canon importance
blocks.description: Decide the official role each brand or label plays inside the AtlasForge universe and how boldly we present that role to the public.

items.label: What role should the AtlasForge umbrella play in official canon?
items.description: Establishes how authoritative the AtlasForge name is across worlds and tools, from background organizer to flagship house.

items.label: How official is Atlas-V as the creative intelligence within the universe?
items.description: Decides whether Atlas-V is treated as a tagged component or the flagship brain driving how AtlasForge builds and speaks.

items.label: How formally is AtlasStudio recognized as the maker's workshop in canon?
items.description: Sets whether AtlasStudio is a light-side utility or a primary studio brand shaping how creators engage with AtlasForge.

items.label: How official is the Atlas Engine identity alongside Atlas-V?
items.description: Clarifies if Atlas Engine is a background technology tag or a major brand representing the core runtime in-world and on-site.

items.label: How recognized is the AtlasForge Media imprint in canon?
items.description: Decides whether Media is a quiet label or a major storytelling brand credited across releases.

items.label: How canonized is the AtlasForge Games brand?
items.description: Determines if Games is a supporting studio mark or a flagship brand fronting our playable worlds.

items.label: How official is SKB / the audio label within the universe?
items.description: Sets whether SKB is a niche craft guild or a prominent sound house credited across experiences.

items.label: What canon weight should VoiceForge carry as a voice/talent label?
items.description: Controls whether VoiceForge is a small background tag or a major voice guild in the AtlasForge story.

items.label: How seriously is Hypercasual Forge treated as an official line?
items.description: Determines if Hypercasual Forge is a future experiment or an active label for lightweight releases in the canon.

items.label: How official is Template Factory as a canon offering?
items.description: Clarifies whether Template Factory is a support utility or a recognized label for starter kits in-world.

items.label: What role should MerchForge play in the AtlasForge canon?
items.description: Sets whether MerchForge is a quiet logistics arm or a branded market house acknowledged across lore and site.

items.label: How canonized is Narrative Labs as a storytelling R&D wing?
items.description: Decides if Narrative Labs is a future-skunkworks mention or a recognized creative lab influencing public releases.

items.label: How visible is Documentary Labs as part of the canon studio slate?
items.description: Determines whether Documentary Labs sits in the background or is acknowledged as a major non-fiction production house.

items.label: How should we frame the AtlasForge Media label across channels?
items.description: Sets whether AtlasForge Media is treated as a tag-of-convenience or a unified imprint that groups all media stories.

blocks.title: Narrative tone for each brand in canon
blocks.description: Select the voice each brand uses when speaking in-world and on the site, balancing practical signals with the shared AtlasForge story.

items.label: What narrative tone should the AtlasForge umbrella use?
items.description: Decides whether AtlasForge speaks in practical coordination or leans into warm, playful, or deep-lore voice across canon.

items.label: What voice should Atlas-V use when it speaks in-world?
items.description: Sets whether Atlas-V sounds neutral, inviting, experimental, bold, or lore-heavy in both narrative and UI cues.

items.label: How should AtlasStudio sound as the maker-facing workshop?
items.description: Determines if AtlasStudio messaging is pragmatic, welcoming, playful, assertive, or steeped in world lore.

items.label: What tone should AtlasForge Media adopt in canon releases?
items.description: Decides whether Media speaks plainly, warmly, experimentally, boldly, or with deep lore references.

items.label: How should Octopus in Action speak in-world and on pages?
items.description: Sets whether OIA messaging is practical, inviting, playful, distinctive, or heavy with narrative backstory.

items.label: What voice fits Neighborhood Watch within the canon?
items.description: Determines if Neighborhood Watch is framed as grounded, welcoming, quirky, bold, or lore-rich when mentioned publicly.

items.label: How should the Atlas Engine speak when referenced?
items.description: Defines whether the engine is described plainly or with a more adventurous or lore-heavy tone in docs and surfaces.

items.label: What tone should SKB / the audio label use in canon?
items.description: Sets whether SKB communications feel neutral, warm, playful, bold, or deeply narrative.

items.label: How should Atlas-V Lite address users in the story?
items.description: Determines if Atlas-V Lite is a straightforward helper or a more characterful, lore-aware companion in messaging.

items.label: What tone should Hypercasual Forge use when spoken about?
items.description: Decides whether Hypercasual Forge feels purely functional or leans into playful, bold, or lore-tinted language.

blocks.title: Atlas-V identity, behavior, and storytelling depth
blocks.description: Define how Atlas-V is framed as the creative engine within the universe and how much of its inner workings and guardrails we reveal to visitors.

items.label: How should Atlas-V be introduced as a character or system in canon?
items.description: Clarifies whether Atlas-V is framed as a tool, a guide, or a flagship intelligence shaping AtlasForge worlds and messaging.

items.label: How much detail should we share about Atlas-V phases and runs?
items.description: Sets whether we stick to taglines or dive into short, detailed, or deep technical storytelling about how the engine operates.

items.label: How visible are Atlas-V governance and guardrails in public canon?
items.description: Decides whether governance stays hidden or is surfaced as footer notes, minor sections, or major explanations for visitors.

items.label: How much should we hint at Atlas-V's internal mechanics?
items.description: Controls whether we obscure the internals or reveal loops, data paths, and safeguards as part of the narrative.

items.label: How wide is Atlas-V's scope in the canon narrative?
items.description: Determines if Atlas-V is positioned as a narrow assistant or the broad creative brain behind tools, media, and games.

items.label: How explicitly should we describe the Atlas-V creative loops?
items.description: Sets whether loops are hidden, lightly referenced, or highlighted as core to how AtlasForge builds worlds.

items.label: How do we position Atlas-V's safety stance in-world and publicly?
items.description: Clarifies if safety is implied, softly stated, or foregrounded as a key trait of the engine's personality and controls.

items.label: How is Atlas-V Lite related to the main Atlas-V in canon?
items.description: Determines whether Lite is a quiet companion, a sibling tool, or a clearly framed entry-tier persona for the engine.

items.label: What style of call-to-action should invite people to Atlas-V?
items.description: Sets whether CTAs are subtle tags or bolder invitations that portray Atlas-V as a guide, partner, or commanding flagship.

items.label: How deep should Atlas-V examples go when shown publicly?
items.description: Controls whether examples stay high-level or become detailed walkthroughs that expose canon processes.

items.label: How should the decision engine itself be referenced in canon?
items.description: Determines if the engine is quietly mentioned, cited in footers, or highlighted as part of the public story about how decisions are locked.

items.label: How should Atlas-V speak when personified?
items.description: Sets the persona voice from neutral guide to lore-heavy character when Atlas-V addresses users or appears in copy.

blocks.title: AtlasStudio surface, scope, and canon framing
blocks.description: Decide how AtlasStudio is positioned as the builder's workshop in the AtlasForge story and how much of its interface, data, and use cases appear publicly.

items.label: How present should the AtlasStudio page be in the public canon map?
items.description: Decides whether AtlasStudio is hidden, labs-only, or showcased as a hero tool page signaling the builder's workshop.

items.label: How should AtlasStudio be framed as an in-universe workshop?
items.description: Determines if AtlasStudio is pitched as a labs experiment or a major forge where creators craft AtlasForge experiences.

items.label: How much of AtlasStudio's capability should be canonized now?
items.description: Sets whether scope stays minimal or expands to show breadth of creation tools and pipelines in public storytelling.

items.label: How much UI detail should we reveal for AtlasStudio?
items.description: Controls if we keep the interface abstract or showcase detailed screens that anchor the workshop in canon.

items.label: Do we call out AtlasStudio tabs or modules in the story?
items.description: Determines whether feature areas are merely hinted at or explicitly named as parts of the workshop experience.

items.label: How is AtlasStudio positioned relative to Atlas-V in canon?
items.description: Clarifies whether AtlasStudio is presented as the hands guided by Atlas-V or as a peer toolset with its own agency.

items.label: How strong should the AtlasStudio invitation be?
items.description: Sets whether CTAs are light teasers or bold hero prompts to enter the workshop and start building.

items.label: How much team story do we share around AtlasStudio?
items.description: Controls whether team credits and craft are quietly referenced or highlighted as part of the workshop lore.

items.label: How should powered-by messaging link AtlasStudio to Atlas-V/Engine?
items.description: Determines if the connection is subtle or prominently canonized as the workshop being fueled by Atlas-V and the engine.

items.label: How broad should public use cases for AtlasStudio be?
items.description: Sets whether we mention a few examples or showcase a wide range of creations to cement its role in the universe.

items.label: How do we frame the AtlasStudio data layer in canon?
items.description: Clarifies whether data foundations stay internal or are presented as a defining piece of how the workshop operates.

items.label: How deep should AtlasStudio demos go for the public?
items.description: Controls whether demos are light teasers or full walkthroughs that reveal process and craft in-world.

blocks.title: Site structure and navigational canon signals
blocks.description: Choose how the site map itself tells the AtlasForge story, from what earns a nav slot to whether hubs stay combined or branch into distinct lore stops.

items.label: How should the Home page anchor the canon story?
items.description: Decides whether Home is a light portal or a primary hub weaving together the AtlasForge narrative for visitors.

items.label: What prominence should the Atlas-V page have in navigation?
items.description: Determines if Atlas-V is hidden from nav or elevated to a primary or hub destination for the engine's story.

items.label: How visible should AtlasStudio be in the nav map?
items.description: Sets whether the workshop is tucked away or clearly reachable as a main path in the canon journey.

items.label: How present is Octopus in Action in the nav and canon tour?
items.description: Controls whether OIA is absent, footer-only, or a primary/hub route for showcasing the world.

items.label: Do we maintain an alternate Octopus entry in navigation?
items.description: Decides if a duplicate/experimental Octopus link exists and how prominent it is on the site map.

items.label: How should SKB / audio content appear in navigation?
items.description: Determines whether the audio house is absent, tucked in the footer, or given nav real estate as part of canon.

items.label: How visible should the Games hub be in navigation?
items.description: Sets whether playable worlds have no nav slot or rise to primary/hub placement for the canon tour.

items.label: How prominent should the Media hub be in navigation?
items.description: Decides if media stories live quietly or earn a primary nav path that frames the universe.

items.label: How should the About/Studio story appear in navigation?
items.description: Controls whether the studio story is hidden, footer-only, or central in the nav for world context.

items.label: How do we surface the Studio tools page in nav?
items.description: Determines if tools stay off the map or become a primary route for builders in the canon journey.

items.label: Should tools and engines stay grouped or split into separate hubs?
items.description: Decides if the ecosystem remains combined or branches into multiple nav hubs, guiding how visitors perceive the world map.

items.label: How visible should the Roadmap be as part of canon?
items.description: Sets whether the roadmap is absent, footer-only, or a major nav destination that signals future lore.

items.label: How present should Governance/Safety be in the nav?
items.description: Determines if governance is hidden, lightly linked, or elevated to primary navigation for transparency.

items.label: How prominent should the Contact / Work With Us page be?
items.description: Clarifies whether entryways for partners and recruits are minimized or surfaced as main nav routes.

items.label: How visible should Merch be in navigation?
items.description: Decides if merch is omitted, footer-linked, or positioned as a primary/hub path in the canon journey.

items.label: What presence should Blog/Devlog have in nav?
items.description: Controls whether ongoing posts are hidden or surfaced to show the living canon.

items.label: How should Labs appear in navigation?
items.description: Determines if experiments are off-map, footer-noted, or given nav space as a living R&D area.

items.label: Do we group media lanes under a single label in nav?
items.description: Decides if media entries remain separate or consolidate into a hub, affecting how visitors read the canon structure.

items.description: Sets whether the homepage lightly introduces the world or foregrounds a full section explaining the AtlasForge canon.

items.label: How prominently should Atlas-V appear on the homepage?
items.description: Determines if Atlas-V is merely tagged or featured with a full section or hero presence as the creative intelligence.

items.label: How visible should AtlasStudio be on the homepage?
items.description: Controls whether the workshop is only hinted at or given a full/hero treatment inviting builders.

items.label: How much should Octopus in Action be showcased on the homepage?
items.description: Decides if OIA is omitted or highlighted as a flagship world anchoring the canon for visitors.

items.label: How do we feature Labs/under-construction work on the homepage?
items.description: Sets whether experiments stay hidden or appear as teasers or sections signaling ongoing lore.

items.label: How visible should governance and safety be on the homepage?
items.description: Determines if governance is absent, a footer note, or a notable section explaining guardrails in-world.

items.label: How prominent should Contact / Work With Us be on the homepage?
items.description: Clarifies whether outreach is tucked away or made a strong invitation within the home narrative.

items.label: How much Media presence should the homepage carry?
items.description: Sets whether media stories are omitted or showcased to demonstrate the AtlasForge storytelling wing.

items.label: How visibly should Games outputs appear on the homepage?
items.description: Decides if games are absent, lightly teased, or celebrated as full sections or hero material.

items.label: How much should the Atlas Engine be explained on the homepage?
items.description: Determines whether the engine is hidden, briefly noted, or given a full section describing its role in canon.

items.label: How prominently should case studies/examples feature on the homepage?
items.description: Sets whether detailed examples remain off-page or are elevated to sections that prove the canon in action.

items.label: How much roadmap content should live on the homepage?
items.description: Decides if future plans are omitted or teased/featured to show where the universe is heading.

items.label: How present should Merch be on the homepage?
items.description: Controls whether the market is absent, teased, or spotlighted as part of the core story.

items.label: How visible should testimonials/quotes be on the homepage?
items.description: Determines if external voices stay hidden or become proof points anchoring trust in the canon narrative.

items.label: How strong should the newsletter/signup invite be?
items.description: Sets whether ongoing updates are omitted or highlighted as a primary way to follow the evolving universe.

items.label: What status should Hypercasual Forge hold in canon?

items.label: How official is Template Factory as part of the universe?
items.description: Sets whether template kits are speculative, side offerings, or a core label for starter packs.

items.label: What canon priority should MerchForge receive?
items.description: Determines if MerchForge is a future idea, a side logistics arm, or a core branded market.

items.label: How active is Narrative Labs within the canon?
items.description: Clarifies whether narrative experiments are dormant, occasional, or a core creative label.

items.label: What standing should Documentary Labs have?
items.description: Decides if documentary work is future, side, or a major line in the AtlasForge slate.

items.label: How recognized is VoiceForge as a canon voice/talent line?
items.description: Sets whether VoiceForge is exploratory, a side label, or a core provider across worlds.

items.label: How prominent should SKB / audio label be as a line?
items.description: Determines if SKB is inactive, occasional, or a core label for sound across the universe.

items.label: How official is the game tools line within the canon?
items.description: Clarifies whether game tools are experimental, side offerings, or core builder kits tied to AtlasForge.

items.label: How should we treat media labeling as a line?

items.label: What status should the general Labs bucket have?

items.label: How should Partnerships be positioned as a line?
items.description: Determines if partnerships are paused, invite-only, or a core canon pillar for co-creation.

items.label: What role should Education/learning play in canon?

items.label: How active should Toolkits/starter packs be?

items.label: What standing should Research notes have in canon?
items.description: Sets whether research remains internal, occasional, or a core stream of published insights.

items.label: What is Octopus in Action's production status in canon?
items.description: Clarifies whether OIA is concept-only or advanced toward flagship release within the universe.

items.label: How visible should Octopus in Action be to the public?
items.description: Determines if OIA stays internal, softly mentioned, or highlighted as a flagship world on the site.

items.label: What is Neighborhood Watch's production status in canon?
items.description: Sets whether Neighborhood Watch is an idea, prototype, or active development line in the slate.

items.label: How visible should Neighborhood Watch be publicly?
items.description: Decides if the title is hidden, hinted, or promoted as a major world.

items.label: How should we handle flagship game rotation in canon?
items.description: Clarifies whether we avoid naming flagships, rotate mentions, or lock a world as the lead signal.

items.label: How much of the game backlog should we list publicly?
items.description: Determines if backlog titles stay internal or appear as future-phase teasers in the canon.

items.label: How should powered-by messaging connect games to Atlas-V/Engine?
items.description: Sets whether engine mentions are omitted, subtle, or boldly tying worlds to our technology.

items.label: How openly should we describe game update cadence?

items.label: How deep should public demos for OIA go?

items.label: How many new IP slots should we acknowledge in canon?

items.label: How do we position game services work (co-dev/ports) in canon?
items.description: Clarifies whether services stay hidden or are presented as an active line alongside our own IP.

items.label: How tightly should games cross-promote AtlasStudio/Atlas-V?
items.description: Determines if cross-promo is omitted or made a visible part of how worlds tie back to the tools.

items.label: How should games link to merch in canon?
items.description: Sets whether merch tie-ins are absent, hinted, or strongly connected to each world publicly.

items.label: What focus should true crime/mystery media have in canon?
items.description: Decides if this lane is inactive or rises to major/flagship series status in our storytelling mix.

items.label: How active should educational/STEM media be?
items.description: Clarifies whether educational content is occasional or a major focus within the universe.

items.label: How prominent should commentary/essay content be?
items.description: Determines if commentary is rare, regular, or a flagship way we speak to the audience.

items.label: How visible should devlogs/behind-the-scenes media be?

items.label: How should we frame coming-soon media in canon?

items.label: How much detail about distribution channels should we share?

items.label: How openly should we state media release cadence?

items.label: How visible should safety/governance notes be in media?

items.label: How much emphasis on interactive media experiments should we show?

items.label: How should media connect to merch in canon?

items.description: Sets whether governance lives internally or gains page presence that signals our guardrails to the public.

items.label: How transparent should governance decisions be in canon?
items.description: Determines if we only hint at oversight or provide summaries/examples or deep public documentation.

items.label: How should we frame the engine's governance posture?
items.description: Clarifies whether governance is implied or explicitly described as part of the Atlas-V/engine story.

items.label: How much should we mention internal governance tools?

items.label: How openly should we acknowledge Atlas-V constraints?

items.label: How explicit should compliance statements be?

items.label: How should people reach governance/safety contacts?

items.label: How much should we link to public governance docs?

items.label: How explicit should we be about our intended audience?

items.label: How open should feedback channels be for governance topics?

items.description: Sets whether partner outreach is closed, filtered, or proactively encouraged as part of the storyline.

items.label: What hiring signals should we send in canon?
items.description: Determines if hiring is silent, invite-only, or openly promoted as part of the world narrative.

items.label: How should newsletter opt-in be framed?
items.description: Clarifies whether ongoing updates are discouraged, filtered, or proactively invited to follow the canon.

items.label: How visible should social links be as channels into the universe?

items.label: How open should press/media contact be?

items.label: How do we frame community hubs in canon?
